questions.question: In Milgram's 1963 study on obedience, what percentage of participants administered the maximum shock of 450V when the experimenter was present in the same room?
questions.explanation: Milgram found that 65% of participants administered the maximum shock when the experimenter was present

questions.question: According to Tarnow's 2000 study on aviation accidents, what was a significant factor contributing to crashes?
questions.explanation: Tarnow found that excessive dependence on the captain's authority contributed to errors in 19 of the 37 accidents studied. This corresponds to: Excessive dependence on captain's authority.

questions.question: In a variation of Milgram's study, what effect did having two disobedient confederates have on the participant's obedience levels?
questions.explanation: When participants were with two disobedient confederates, only 10% continued to the maximum shock level, indicating decreased obedience

questions.question: What is one factor that has been shown to decrease obedience according to research on social influence?
options: High status of the authority figure
questions.explanation: Research indicates that having an ally who disobeys can significantly decrease an individual's obedience

questions.question: What does the concept of 'legitimacy of authority' imply in the context of obedience?
options: People obey due to peer pressure
Obedience is higher in familiar settings
Individuals feel justified in harming others under authority
Obedience is solely based on personality traits
questions.explanation: Legitimacy of authority suggests that individuals may justify harmful actions when directed by a legitimate authority figure. This corresponds to: Individuals feel justified in harming others under authority.

questions.question: In the context of obedience, how does the agentic state affect an individual's behavior?
options: It leads to higher levels of disobedience
It allows individuals to see themselves as agents of the authority
questions.explanation: The agentic state allows individuals to view themselves as agents executing the wishes of an authority figure, reducing personal responsibility. This corresponds to: It allows individuals to see themselves as agents of the authority.

questions.question: What was the main finding of Elms and Milgram's study regarding the Authoritarian Personality?
options: Higher obedience is linked to lower education
Obedience is unrelated to personality traits
Participants with Authoritarian Personality scored higher on the F scale
Disobedience is more common among authoritarian individuals
questions.explanation: Elms and Milgram found that participants who were obedient in Milgram's study scored higher on the F scale, indicating a link to the Authoritarian Personality. This corresponds to: Participants with Authoritarian Personality scored higher on the F scale.

questions.question: What methodological issue is raised by Fromm regarding Milgram's study on obedience?
questions.explanation: Fromm suggested that Milgram's laboratory setting may not accurately reflect real-life obedience, which often requires more time and manipulation. This corresponds to: The lack of real-life applicability.

questions.question: What role does education level play in obedience according to research findings?
options: Higher education correlates with higher obedience
Lower education correlates with higher obedience
Education has no effect on obedience
Education level is irrelevant to obedience
questions.explanation: Research indicates that less-educated individuals tend to be more obedient than those with higher levels of education. This corresponds to: Lower education correlates with higher obedience.

questions.question: How does the presence of disobedient peers influence an individual's likelihood to obey authority?
questions.explanation: Research shows that disobedient peers can empower individuals to resist authority, thereby decreasing their likelihood to obey. This corresponds to: It decreases obedience.
